original: Genetic deficiency or pharmacological blockade of P2X7R led to branching deficits under physiological conditions.
Moreover, pathologic activation of the receptor led to deficits in dendritic outgrowth on primary neurons from WT mice but not those from P2X7R KO mice exposed to MIA.
incorrect: Genetic deficiency or pharmacological blockade of P2X7R led to branching surpluses under physiological conditions.
Moreover, pathologic activation of the receptor led to surpluses in dendritic outgrowth on primary neurons from WT mice but not those from P2X7R KO mice exposed to MIA.

original: Moreover, the absence of endogenous creatine resulted in altered AMPK signaling in the brain, reduced brain creatine kinase expression in cortical neurons, and signs of axonal damage.

Experimental demyelination in mice after tamoxifen-induced conditional deletion of Gamt in oligodendrocyte lineage cells resulted in delayed maturation of oligodendrocytes and myelin coverage in lesions.
Moreover, creatine and cyclocreatine supplementation can enhance remyelination after demyelination.
incorrect: Moreover, the absence of endogenous creatine resulted in altered AMPK signaling in the brain, increased brain creatine kinase expression in cortical neurons, and signs of axonal damage.

Experimental demyelination in mice after tamoxifen-induced conditional deletion of Gamt in oligodendrocyte lineage cells resulted in early maturation of oligodendrocytes and myelin coverage in lesions.
Moreover, creatine and cyclocreatine supplementation can suppress remyelination after demyelination.

original: Silencing neuronal activity in ORNs, PNs, and LNs impaired synaptic development but only in ORNs did enhancing neuronal activity influence synapse formation.

ORNs and LNs demonstrated similar impairment of synaptic development with enhanced activity of a master kinase, GSK-3β, suggesting that neuronal activity and GSK-3β kinase activity function in a common pathway.
ORNs also, however, demonstrated impaired synaptic development with GSK-3β loss-of-function, suggesting additional activity-independent roles in development.
incorrect: Silencing neuronal activity in ORNs, PNs, and LNs enhanced synaptic development but only in ORNs did impairing neuronal activity influence synapse formation.

ORNs and LNs demonstrated similar enhancement of synaptic development with enhanced activity of a master kinase, GSK-3β, suggesting that neuronal activity and GSK-3β kinase activity function in a common pathway.
ORNs also, however, demonstrated enhanced synaptic development with GSK-3β loss-of-function, suggesting additional activity-independent roles in development.

original: At weeks 7-8 after hemisection, the proportion of complete clearance increased, Other responses decreased, and stumbling corrective reactions remained relatively unchanged.
We found redistribution of weight support after hemisection, with reduced diagonal supports and increased homolateral supports, particularly on the left contralesional side.
The increase in complete clearance over time after hemisection paralleled the recovery of muscle activation patterns or new strategies.
incorrect: At weeks 7-8 after hemisection, the proportion of complete clearance decreased, Other responses increased, and stumbling corrective reactions remained relatively unchanged.
We found redistribution of weight support after hemisection, with increased diagonal supports and decreased homolateral supports, particularly on the right contralesional side.
The decrease in complete clearance over time after hemisection diverged from the recovery of muscle activation patterns or new strategies.

original: We found that the structural and functional development of excitatory and inhibitory synapses at DIV9 was not affected after VU treatment.

Surprisingly, 14 d after the VU treatment had ended (DIV21), we observed an increased frequency of spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents in CA1 pyramidal cells, while excitatory currents were not changed.
We found that dendrite-targeting interneurons in the stratum radiatum had an elevated resting membrane potential, while pyramidal cells were less excitable compared with control slices.

Our results show that depolarizing GABA signaling does not promote synapse formation after P7, and suggest that postnatal intracellular chloride levels indirectly affect membrane properties in a cell-specific manner.
incorrect: We found that the structural and functional development of excitatory but not inhibitory synapses at DIV9 was affected after VU treatment.

Surprisingly, 14 d after the VU treatment had ended (DIV21), we observed an increased frequency of spontaneous inhibitory postsynaptic currents in CA2 pyramidal cells, while excitatory currents were not changed.
We found that dendrite-targeting interneurons in the molecular layer had an reduced resting membrane potential, while pyramidal cells were more excitable compared with control slices.

Our results show that depolarizing GABA signaling promotes synapse formation after P7, and suggest that postnatal intracellular chloride levels indirectly affect membrane properties in a cell-specific manner.

original: The best results were observed in the group that received combinational AAV-NG2Ab+AAV-NT3 treatment.
incorrect: The best results were observed in the group that received AAV-NG2Ab only treatment.

original: We set out to elucidate the extracellular pH transients that occur at this cholinergic synapse under near-physiological conditions and identify their sources.
Using mice from both sexes, a significant and prolonged alkalization occurred when stimulating the connected nerve for 5 s at 50 Hz, which was dependent on postsynaptic intracellular Ca2+ release.

Thus, cholinergic synapses of the mouse NMJ typically alkalize because of cytosolic Ca2+ liberated in muscle during activity, unless under highly strenuous conditions where acidification predominates.
incorrect: We set out to elucidate the extracellular pH transients that occur at this glutamatergic synapse under near-physiological conditions and identify their sources.
Using mice from both sexes, a significant reduction of alkalization occurred when stimulating the connected nerve for 5 s at 50 Hz, which was dependent on postsynaptic intracellular Ca2+ release.

Thus, glutamatergic synapses of the mouse NMJ typically alkalize because of cytosolic Ca2+ liberated in muscle during activity, unless under highly strenuous conditions where acidification predominates.

original: Eliminating fusion by knocking down the neuronal mitochondrial fusion protein mitofusin 2 (MFN2) reduced the rates of axonal mitochondrial trafficking and fusion, decreased the levels of synaptic vesicle (SV) proteins, inhibited exocytosis, and impaired SV recruitment from the reserve pool during extended stimulation.
MFN2 knockdown also resulted in presynaptic Ca2+ dyshomeostasis.
Remarkably, upon MFN2 knockdown, presynaptic mitochondria sequestered Ca2+ more efficiently, effectively limiting presynaptic Ca2+ transients during stimulation.
incorrect: Eliminating fusion by overexpressing the neuronal mitochondrial fusion protein mitofusin 2 (MFN2) reduced the rates of axonal mitochondrial trafficking and fusion, decreased the levels of synaptic vesicle (SV) proteins, inhibited exocytosis, and impaired SV recruitment from the reserve pool during extended stimulation.
MFN2 overexpression also resulted in presynaptic Ca2+ dyshomeostasis.
Remarkably, upon MFN2 overexpression, presynaptic mitochondria sequestered Ca2+ more efficiently, effectively limiting presynaptic Ca2+ transients during stimulation.

original: Further, intracellular structures were often shared between assemblies, entangling them to form larger complexes or association domains, often in small clusters of vesicles.

Our findings suggest that transsynaptic assemblies physically connect the three compartments, allow for coordinated molecular organization, and may combine to form specialized functional association domains, resembling the light-level nanocolumns.
incorrect: Further, intercellular structures were often shared within assemblies, disintegrating them to form smaller complexes or segregation domains, often in small clusters of vesicles.

Our findings suggest that transsynaptic assemblies physically connect the three compartments, allow for coordinated molecular organization, and may combine to connect specialized functional segregation domains, resembling the light-level nanocolumns.

original: Our results reveal that these male mice have normal basal synaptic transmission but exhibit enhanced LTP and deficits in LTD.
incorrect: Our results reveal that these male mice have normal basal synaptic transmission but exhibit enhanced LTD and deficits in LTP.

original: We found that in both male and female mice, ELS-activated neurons within the nucleus accumbens (NAc), and to a lesser extent the medial prefrontal cortex, were preferentially reactivated by adult stress.

To test whether reactivation of ELS-activated ensembles in the NAc contributes to stress hypersensitivity, we expressed hM4Dis receptor in control or ELS-activated neurons of pups and chemogenetically inhibited their activity during experience of adult stress.
Inhibition of ELS-activated NAc neurons, but not control-tagged neurons, ameliorated social avoidance behavior following chronic social defeat stress in males.
incorrect: We found that in both male and female mice, ELS-activated neurons within the hippocampus (CA1), and to a lesser extent the medial prefrontal cortex, were preferentially reactivated by adult stress.

To test whether reactivation of ELS-activated ensembles in the CA1 contributes to stress hypersensitivity, we expressed hM3Dq receptor in control or ELS-activated neurons of pups and chemogenetically inhibited their activity during experience of adult stress.
Inhibition of ELS-activated CA1 neurons, but not control-tagged neurons, exacerbated social avoidance behavior following chronic social defeat stress in males.

original: Silencing the firing of parvalbumin-positive (PV+) GPe neurons by activating genetically expressed Archaerhodopsin current increased the firing rate and regularity of PV– neurons.
As few as 5 unitary inputs produced large increases in firing irregularity.
The firing rate was also reduced initially, but PV+ neurons exhibited a slow spike-frequency adaptation that partially restored the rate despite sustained inhibition.
incorrect: Silencing the firing of parvalbumin-positive (PV+) GPe neurons by activating genetically expressed Archaerhodopsin current decreased the firing rate and regularity of PV– neurons.
As few as 5 unitary inputs produced large decreases in firing irregularity.
The firing rate was also increased initially, but PV+ neurons exhibited a slow spike-frequency adaptation that partially restored the rate despite sustained disinhibition.

original: APP deficiency altered excitatory neurotransmission at medial perforant path synapses, which was accompanied by transcriptomic and ultrastructural changes.

Moreover, presynaptic but not postsynaptic APP deletion through the local injection of Cre-expressing adeno-associated viruses in conditional APPflox/flox tissue cultures increased the neurotransmission efficacy at perforant path synapses.
incorrect: APP deficiency altered inhibitory neurotransmission at medial perforant path synapses, which was accompanied by transcriptomic and ultrastructural changes.

Moreover, presynaptic but not postsynaptic APP deletion through the local injection of Cre-expressing adeno-associated viruses in conditional APPflox/flox tissue cultures decreased the neurotransmission efficacy at perforant path synapses.

original: Here we found that both focal and generalized convulsive seizures (GCSs) in epilepsy patients caused a prolonged decrease in the hypercapnic ventilatory response (HCVR; a measure of respiratory CO2 chemoreception).

We then studied Scn1aR1407X/+ (Dravet syndrome; DS) and Scn8aN1768D/+ (D/+) mice of both sexes, two models of SUDEP, and found that convulsive seizures caused a postictal decrease in ventilation and severely depressed the HCVR in a subset of animals.
Those mice with severe postictal depression of the HCVR also exhibited transient postictal hypothermia.

Depleting 5-HT with para-chlorophenylalanine (PCPA) mimicked seizure-induced hypoventilation, partially occluded the postictal decrease in the HCVR, exacerbated hypothermia, and increased postictal mortality in DS mice.
Conversely, pretreatment with the 5-HT agonist fenfluramine reduced postictal inhibition of the HCVR and hypothermia.

These results are consistent with the previous observation that seizures cause transient impairment of serotonergic neuron function, which would be expected to inhibit the many aspects of respiratory control dependent on 5-HT, including baseline ventilation and the HCVR.
incorrect: Here we found that both focal and generalized convulsive seizures (GCSs) in epilepsy patients caused a prolonged increase in the hypercapnic ventilatory response (HCVR; a measure of respiratory CO2 chemoreception).

We then studied Scn1aR1407X/+ (Dravet syndrome; DS) and Scn8aN1768D/+ (D/+) mice of both sexes, two models of SUDEP, and found that convulsive seizures caused a postictal increase in ventilation and profoundly elevated the HCVR in a subset of animals.
Those mice with severe postictal enhancement of the HCVR also exhibited transient postictal hyperthermia.

Depleting 5-HT with para-chlorophenylalanine (PCPA) mimicked seizure-induced hyperventilation, partially occluded the postictal increase in the HCVR, exacerbated hyperthermia, and increased postictal mortality in DS mice.
Conversely, pretreatment with the 5-HT agonist fenfluramine reduced postictal enhancement of the HCVR and hyperthermia.

These results are consistent with the previous observation that seizures cause transient impairment of serotonergic neuron function, which would be expected to facilitate the many aspects of respiratory control dependent on 5-HT, including baseline ventilation and the HCVR.

original: Activation of opioid receptors suppresses the firing and inhibitory synaptic transmission of PVT neurons in brain slices.
On the other hand, the involvement of opioid modulation is reduced after chronic morphine exposure, probably because of desensitization and internalization of opioid receptors in the PVT.
incorrect: Activation of opioid receptors enhances the firing and inhibitory synaptic transmission of PVT neurons in brain slices.
On the other hand, the involvement of opioid modulation is reduced after acute morphine exposure, probably because of desensitization and internalization of opioid receptors in the PVT.

original: We studied escitalopram and fluoxetine using new intensity-based, drug-sensing fluorescent reporters targeted to the plasma membrane, cytoplasm, or endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of cultured neurons and mammalian cell lines.

The drugs attain equilibrium in neuronal cytoplasm and ER at approximately the same concentration as the externally applied solution, with time constants of a few s (escitalopram) or 200–300 s (fluoxetine).
Simultaneously, the drugs accumulate within lipid membranes by ≥18-fold (escitalopram) or 180-fold (fluoxetine), and possibly by much larger factors.

The quaternary derivatives are substantially excluded from membrane, cytoplasm, and ER for >2.4 h. They inhibit SERT transport-associated currents sixfold or 11-fold less potently than the SSRIs (escitalopram or fluoxetine derivative, respectively), providing useful probes for distinguishing compartmentalized SSRI effects.
incorrect: We studied sertraline and paroxetine using new intensity-based, drug-sensing fluorescent reporters targeted to the plasma membrane, cytoplasm, or endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of cultured neurons and mammalian cell lines.

The drugs attain equilibrium in neuronal cytoplasm and ER at approximately the same concentration as the externally applied solution, with time constants of a few s (sertraline) or 200–300 s (paroxetine).
Simultaneously, the drugs accumulate within lipid membranes by ≥18-fold (sertraline) or 180-fold (paroxetine), and possibly by much larger factors.

The quaternary derivatives are substantially excluded from membrane, cytoplasm, and ER for >2.4 h. They inhibit SERT transport-associated currents sixfold or 11-fold less potently than the SSRIs (sertraline or paroxetine derivative, respectively), providing useful probes for distinguishing compartmentalized SSRI effects.

original: In this work, we systematically examined the distinct dominant electrophysiological features for four unique IN subtypes in L1 that were previously identified from mice of either gender: Canopy cells show an irregular firing pattern near rheobase; neurogliaform cells are late-spiking, and their firing rate accelerates during current injections; cells with strong expression of the α7 nicotinic receptor (α7 cells), display onset (rebound) bursting; vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) expressing cells exhibit high input resistance, strong adaptation, and irregular firing.
In particular, we show that irregular firing results from square-wave bursting through a fast-slow analysis.
Furthermore, we demonstrate that irregular firing is frequently observed in VIP cells because of the interaction between strong adaptation and a slowly inactivating K+ channel.
incorrect: In this work, we systematically examined the distinct dominant electrophysiological features for four unique IN subtypes in L1 that were previously identified from mice of either gender: Canopy cells show an irregular firing pattern near rheobase; Chandelier cells are late-spiking, and their firing rate accelerates during current injections; cells with strong expression of the α7 nicotinic receptor (α7 cells), display onset (rebound) bursting; vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) expressing cells exhibit high input resistance, strong adaptation, and regular firing.
In particular, we show that regular firing results from square-wave bursting through a fast-slow analysis.
Furthermore, we demonstrate that regular firing is frequently observed in VIP cells because of the interaction between strong adaptation and a slowly inactivating K+ channel.

original: Whole-cell patch-clamp recordings revealed that acid shifts in extracellular pH (pHo) significantly reduce action potential firing in CA1 pyramidal neurons but did not alter firing in hippocampal inhibitory interneurons.
In real-time dynamic clamp experiments, acidification reduced simulated action potential firing generated in hybrid model neurons expressing the excitatory neuron predominant NaV1.2 channel.
Conversely, acidification had no effect on action potential firing in hybrid model neurons expressing the interneuron predominant NaV1.1 channel.

Both carbogen-mediated seizure protection and the reduction in CA1 pyramidal neuron action potential firing by low pHo were maintained in an Asic1a knock-out mouse ruling out this acid-sensing channel as the underlying molecular target.

These data indicate that the acid-mediated reduction in excitatory neuron firing is mediated, at least in part, through the inhibition of NaV1.2 channels, whereas inhibitory neuron firing is unaffected.
This reduction in pyramidal neuron excitability is the likely basis of seizure suppression caused by carbogen-mediated acidification.
incorrect: Whole-cell patch-clamp recordings revealed that acid shifts in extracellular pH (pHo) significantly reduce action potential firing in hippocampal inhibitory interneurons but did not alter firing in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
In real-time dynamic clamp experiments, acidification reduced simulated action potential firing generated in hybrid model neurons expressing the interneuron predominant NaV1.2 channel.
Conversely, acidification had no effect on action potential firing in hybrid model neurons expressing the excitatory neuron predominant NaV1.1 channel.

Both carbogen-mediated seizure protection and the reduction in interneuron action potential firing by low pHo were maintained in an Asic1a knock-out mouse ruling out this acid-sensing channel as the underlying molecular target.

These data indicate that the acid-mediated reduction in interneuron neuron firing is mediated, at least in part, through the inhibition of NaV1.2 channels, whereas excitatory neuron firing is unaffected.
This reduction in interneuron neuron excitability is the likely basis of seizure suppression caused by carbogen-mediated acidification.

original: We identify three channels, LGC-40, LGC-57, and LGC-58, whose primary ligand is choline rather than acetylcholine, as well as the first evidence of a truly polymodal channel, LGC-39, which is activated by both cholinergic and aminergic ligands.

Using our new ligand–receptor pairs we uncover the surprising extent to which single neurons in the hermaphrodite nervous system express both excitatory and inhibitory channels, not only for acetylcholine but also for the other major neurotransmitters.
incorrect: We identify three channels, LGC-40, LGC-57, and LGC-58, whose primary ligand is acetylcholine rather than choline, as well as the first evidence of a truly polymodal channel, LGC-39, which is activated by both cholinergic and histaminic ligands.

Using our new ligand–receptor pairs we uncover the surprising extent to which single neurons in the hermaphrodite nervous system express both excitatory and inhibitory channels, not only for choline but also for the other major neurotransmitters.

original: We find that PKCδ is activated downstream of TrkB and DAG production, and that the spatiotemporal nature of its activation depends on the plasticity stimulation.
incorrect: We find that PKCδ activation leads to TrkB and DAG production, and that the spatiotemporal nature of its activation depends on the plasticity stimulation.

original: After detachment, the hilus, the opening through which postsynaptic processes enter the invagination, enlarges, exposing the normally sequestered environment within the invagination to the extracellular space of the outer plexiform layer.
incorrect: After detachment, the hilus, the opening through which postsynaptic processes enter the invagination, contracts, obscuring the normally sequestered environment within the invagination to the extracellular space of the outer plexiform layer.

original: Nonstationary fluctuation analysis of two-photon evoked unitary synaptic currents showed that the postsynaptic component of E2-induced potentiation occurs either through an increase in AMPAR conductance or in nonconductive properties of AMPARs (number of channels × open probability) and never both at the same synapse.
In females, most synapses (76%) were potentiated via increased AMPAR conductance, whereas in males, more synapses (60%) were potentiated via an increase in nonconductive AMPAR properties.

Inhibition of cpAMPARs eliminated E2-induced synaptic potentiation in females, whereas some synapses in males were unaffected by cpAMPAR inhibition; these synapses in males potentiated exclusively via increased AMPAR nonconductive properties.
incorrect: Nonstationary fluctuation analysis of two-photon evoked unitary synaptic currents showed that the postsynaptic component of E2-induced potentiation occurs either through a decrease in AMPAR conductance or in nonconductive properties of AMPARs (number of channels × open probability) and never both at the same synapse.
In females, most synapses (76%) were potentiated via decreased AMPAR conductance, whereas in males, more synapses (60%) were potentiated via a decrease in nonconductive AMPAR properties.

Inhibition of cpAMPARs eliminated E2-induced synaptic potentiation in females, whereas some synapses in males were unaffected by cpAMPAR inhibition; these synapses in males potentiated exclusively via decreased AMPAR nonconductive properties.

original: Here, we show that the R201C variant in KCNQ2 has opposite effects on the excitability of two types of mouse pyramidal neurons of either sex, causing hyperexcitability in layer 2/3 (L2/3) pyramidal neurons and hypoexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
Similarly, the homologous R231C variant in KCNQ3 leads to hyperexcitability in L2/3 pyramidal neurons and hypoexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
incorrect: Here, we show that the R201C variant in KCNQ2 has opposite effects on the excitability of two types of mouse pyramidal neurons of either sex, causing hypoexcitability in layer 2/3 (L2/3) pyramidal neurons and hyperexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.
Similarly, the homologous R231C variant in KCNQ3 leads to hypoexcitability in L2/3 pyramidal neurons and hyperexcitability in CA1 pyramidal neurons.

original: In adulthood, the neurotransmitter GABA hyperpolarizes dendrites but instead depolarizes axons.

Multiple studies have shown that GABAergic signaling in this region can share properties of either the mature axon or mature dendrite, and that these properties evolve over a protracted period encompassing periadolescent development.
Here, we explored how developmental changes in GABAergic signaling affect AP initiation.

We show that GABA at the axon initial segment inhibits action potential initiation in layer (L)2/3 pyramidal neurons in prefrontal cortex from mice of either sex across GABA reversal potentials observed in periadolescence.

These actions occur largely through current shunts generated by GABAA receptors and changes in voltage-gated channel properties that affected the number of channels that could be recruited for AP electrogenesis.

These results suggest that GABAergic neurons targeting the axon initial segment provide an inhibitory “veto” across the range of GABA polarity observed in normal adolescent development, regardless of GABAergic synapse reversal potential.
incorrect: In adulthood, the neurotransmitter glutamate hyperpolarizes dendrites but instead depolarizes axons.

Multiple studies have shown that glutamatergic signaling in this region can share properties of either the mature axon or mature dendrite, and that these properties evolve over a protracted period encompassing periadolescent development.
Here, we explored how developmental changes in glutamatergic signaling affect AP initiation.

We show that glutamate at the axon initial segment inhibits action potential initiation in layer (L)2/3 pyramidal neurons in prefrontal cortex from mice of either sex across glutamate reversal potentials observed in periadolescence.

These actions occur largely through current shunts generated by NMDA receptors and changes in voltage-gated channel properties that affected the number of channels that could be recruited for AP electrogenesis.

These results suggest that glutamatergic neurons targeting the axon initial segment provide an inhibitory “veto” across the range of glutamate polarity observed in normal adolescent development, regardless of glutamatergic synapse reversal potential.

original: GnRH release increased with higher frequency spontaneous firing to a point; release reached a plateau after which further increases in firing rate did not elicit further increased release.
Kisspeptin, a potent GnRH neuron activator via a Gq-coupled signaling pathway, triggered GnRH release before increasing firing rate, whether globally perfused or locally applied.
Increasing the number of spikes in an applied burst template increased release; orchidectomized mice had higher sensitivity to the increased action potential number than sham-operated mice.
Similarly, Ca2+ currents triggered by these burst templates were increased in GnRH neurons of orchidectomized mice.
incorrect: GnRH release increased with lower frequency spontaneous firing to a point; release reached a plateau after which further decreases in firing rate did not elicit further increased release.
Kisspeptin, a potent GnRH neuron activator via a Gq-coupled signaling pathway, triggered GnRH release before decreasing firing rate, whether globally perfused or locally applied.
Decreasing the number of spikes in an applied burst template increased release; orchidectomized mice had higher sensitivity to the decreased action potential number than sham-operated mice.
Similarly, Ca2+ currents triggered by these burst templates were decreased in GnRH neurons of orchidectomized mice.

original: EndoA1-knockdown significantly reversed Syt11-knockout phenotype, identifying EndoA1 as a main inhibitory target of Syt11 during SV endocytosis.
Application of this peptide inhibited SV endocytosis in wild-type hippocampal neurons but not in EndoA1-knockdown neurons.
Moreover, intracellular application of this peptide in mouse calyx of Held terminals of either sex effectively hampered both fast and slow SV endocytosis at physiological temperature.
We thus propose that Syt11 ensures the precision of protein retrieval during SV endocytosis by inhibiting EndoA1 function at neuronal terminals.
incorrect: EndoA1-knockdown significantly reversed Syt11-knockout phenotype, identifying EndoA1 as a main excitatory target of Syt11 during SV endocytosis.
Application of this peptide facilitated SV endocytosis in wild-type hippocampal neurons but not in EndoA1-knockdown neurons.
Moreover, intracellular application of this peptide in mouse calyx of Held terminals of either sex effectively assisted both fast and slow SV endocytosis at physiological temperature.
We thus propose that Syt11 ensures the precision of protein retrieval during SV endocytosis by facilitating EndoA1 function at neuronal terminals.

original: The nanoGFP-based probes allowed faster lateral diffusion of the NMDARs, with several-fold increased median values of the diffusion coefficient (D).

Using thresholded tdTomato-Homer1c signals to mark synaptic regions, we found that the nanoprobe-based D values sharply increased at distances over 100 nm from the synaptic edge, while D values for antiGFP-QD605 probe remained unchanged up to a 400 nm distance.
incorrect: The nanoGFP-based probes allowed slower lateral diffusion of the NMDARs, with several-fold decreased median values of the diffusion coefficient (D).

Using thresholded tdTomato-Homer1c signals to mark synaptic regions, we found that the nanoprobe-based D values sharply decreased at distances over 100 nm from the synaptic edge, while D values for antiGFP-QD605 probe remained unchanged up to a 400 nm distance.

original: In the present study, we identified two potential sodium-binding sites in the C-terminal domain of the rat Slack channel by conducting electrophysical recordings and systematic mutagenesis of cytosolic acidic residues in the rat Slack channel C terminus.

Furthermore, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations performed at the hundreds of nanoseconds timescale revealed one or two sodium ions at the E373 position or an acidic pocket composed of several negatively charged residues.
incorrect: In the present study, we identified three potential sodium-binding sites in the C-terminal domain of the rat Slack channel by conducting electrophysical recordings and systematic mutagenesis of cytosolic acidic residues in the rat Slack channel C terminus.

Furthermore, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations performed at the hundreds of nanoseconds timescale revealed one or two sodium ions at the M335A position or an acidic pocket composed of several negatively charged residues.

original: Using patch-clamp electrophysiology in brain slices prepared from male rats, we reveal that opioid withdrawal abruptly reduces the ability of these peptides to inhibit neurotransmission, a direct consequence of a protein kinase A (PKA)-driven increase in the synaptic activity of peptidases.
incorrect: Using patch-clamp electrophysiology in brain slices prepared from male rats, we reveal that opioid withdrawal abruptly increases the ability of these peptides to inhibit neurotransmission, a direct consequence of a protein kinase A (PKA)-driven increase in the synaptic activity of peptidases.

original: Double-mutant cycle analysis and double cysteine mutant of these two residues proved that these two residues cooperatively form a proton-sensitive site.
Furthermore, the PAC channel knock-out (KO) male mice (C57BL/6J) resist chloral hydrate-induced sedation and hypnosis.
incorrect: Double-mutant cycle analysis and double cysteine mutant of these two residues proved that these two residues independently form a proton-sensitive site.
Furthermore, the PAC channel knock-out (KO) male mice (C57BL/6J) respond to chloral hydrate-induced sedation and hypnosis.

original: CUL3-deficient mice exhibited hyperactive locomotion, deficits in working memory and sensorimotor gating, and increased sensitivity to psychostimulants.
incorrect: CUL3-deficient mice exhibited hypoactive locomotion, deficits in working memory and sensorimotor gating, and decreased sensitivity to psychostimulants.
